text: The first principle is that you must not fool yourself— and you are the easiest person to fool.
author: Richard P. Feynman (1918–1988)

text: The computer is incredibly fast, accurate, and stupid.Man is unbelievably slow, inaccurate, and brilliant.Together they are powerful beyond imagination.
author: Leo Cherne (1912–1999)

text: Everything should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler.
author: Albert Einstein (1879–1955)

text: All models are wrong, but some are useful.
author: George E. P. Box (1919–2013)

text: The map is not the territory.
author: Alfred Korzybski (1879–1950)

text: Keep your identity small.
author: Paul Graham (b. 1964)

text: In God we trust; all others must bring data.
author: W. Edwards Deming (1900–1993) — attributed

text: The purpose of computing is insight, not numbers.
author: Richard Hamming (1915–1998)

text: How you do one thing is how you do everything.
author: Unknown — commonly attributed to Martha Beck (b. 1962) and T. Harv Eker (b. 1954)

text: If you see fraud and do not say fraud, you are a fraud.
author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb (b. 1960)

text: The only way out is through.
author: Robert Frost

text: We can be blind to the obvious, and we are also blind to our blindness.
author: Daniel Kahneman (b. 1934)

text: Everyone has a plan until they get punched in the mouth.
author: Mike Tyson (b. 1966)

text: It is difficult to get a man to understand something, when his salary depends upon his not understanding it.
author: Upton Sinclair (1878–1968)

text: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.
author: Marilyn Strathern (b. 1941)

text: The most dangerous phrase in the language is, 'We've always done it this way.'
author: Grace Hopper (1906–1992)

text: Young man, in mathematics you don't understand things. You just get used to them.
author: John von Neumann (1903–1957)

text: Real artists ship.
author: Steve Jobs (1955–2011)

text: Strong opinions, loosely held.
author: Paul Saffo (b. 1954)

text: We tend to overestimate the effect of a technology in the short run and underestimate the effect in the long run.
author: Roy Amara (1925–2007)

text: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.
author: Arthur C. Clarke (1917–2008)

text: Competition is for losers.
author: Peter Thiel (b. 1967)

text: Play long-term games with long-term people.
author: Naval Ravikant (b. 1974)

text: A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing its opponents and making them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die.
author: Max Planck (1858–1947)

text: No man ever steps in the same river twice, for it's not the same river and he's not the same man.
author: Heraclitus (c. 535–475 BC)
